Replace.Text: [B]+100% Yields[/B] from [icon:Action_Pillage] [B]Pillaging[/B] and [B]Coastal Raiding[/B] with Naval Units. [icon:UNIT_SETTLER] Settlers cannot be trained or purchased, but you can capture other Civilizations' [icon:UNIT_SETTLER] Settlers. Naval, Treasure Convoy, and Buccaneer Units can move into other Civilization's borders without being at [icon:WAR] War or having Open Borders.

[BLIST][LI][B]+100% Yields[/B] from [icon:Action_Pillage] [B]Pillaging[/B] and [B]Coastal Raiding[/B] with Naval Units. [LI][icon:UNIT_SETTLER] [B]Settlers[/B] cannot be trained or purchased, but you can capture other Civilizations' [icon:UNIT_SETTLER] [B]Settlers[/B].[LI][B]Naval, Treasure Convoy, and Buccaneer Units[/B] can move into other [B]Civilization's[/B] borders without being at [icon:WAR] [B]War[/B] or having [B]Open Borders[/B].[LI][B]+30%[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production [/B]towards constructing [B]Havana Harbor[/B].[/LIST]
+30% [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production from being the Republic of Pirates's associated [icon:WONDER] Wonder.

Trade in the 17th and early 18th century moved immense amounts of wealth through uncontrolled, unpredictable regions. Galleons, however fearsome, were the mercy of wind and water… and whoever was bold enough to attempt to seize them. Were this not already an enticement to piracy, the powers of the day fostered independent raiders – privateers - as a means of cutting off their rivals’ revenue. But these privateers could just as quickly turn pirate if the opportunity presented itself.

In 1694, the Charles II waited in port in the Spanish city of Corunna, and its crew grumbled. The Spanish crown had promised a letter of marque enabling the Charles II to attack and plunder Spain’s rivals, but the letter had yet to arrive. When the crew’s wages, too, failed to come, the crew mutinied and, under former first mate Henry Every, seized the ship and sailed it to attack and plunder with or without a letter. They, in other words, “went on account,” went pirate.

The Fancy, as the Charles II was rechristened, sailed to the Indian Ocean and took an impressive prize: the Ganj-i-Sawai and Fateh Muhammad, Mughal vessels carrying a fortune in gold and jewels. Every took this wealth and sailed to Nassau (in the present-day Bahamas), where he bribed the English governor to turn a blind eye towards the pirates. Not that the governor had much of a choice - he was the administrator of a distant colony of a minor (at that point) European power, and here under Every was a battle-hardened force armed to the teeth, offering him a fortune to simply do nothing.

But with this new deal, pirates flooded into Nassau and, as the civilian population dwindled, Nassau (called, more often, Providence) became a pirate town. Benjamin Hornigold, an English privateer, formed the “Flying Gang”, a band of pirates that operated out of the city and flew the death’s head flag, and whose members boasted names such as Edward “Blackbeard” Teach, “Calico” Jack Rackham, Anne Bonny, Henry Jennings, Mary Read, as well as the republic’s self-appointed governor, Thomas Barrow.

The ”republic” (its name comes from a 2007 book by the historian Colin Woodard; its members referred to their city as Providence and their ships as the Flying Gang) operated on a certain code, one shared by many in the sea at that time. This was a system of consensual autocracy: the captain was the sole dictator of their ship, but, upon enlisting, potential crewmembers agreed to follow and expect certain terms: sharing of all plunder, a system of insurance for those wounded in battle, a vote in important matters, equal access to food and drink. But there were limitations as well: lights onboard were to be put out by eight PM, gambling and the bringing of women onboard ship were forbidden (though Bonny and Read’s presence suggests that this was not universal), and the forbidding of music on Sundays were common.

The pirates of the Republic were drawn mostly from English ships, and Hornigold’s refusal to attack English vessels was a common cause for complaint by many pirates under him. However, in addition to Englishmen (and a few women), there were a sizeable number of pirates from the United States, from Caribbean settlements or Europe, or even from the East Indies. The makeup of pirate crews was more diverse than navies at the time; estimates suggest that roughly 25-30 percent of pirates were of African ancestry and, although pirates considered enslaved people found in the holds of ships to be cargo that could be stolen and sold, free Black crewmembers seem to have been treated relatively equally.

Providence proved an embarrassment for England, and a threat to all legal commerce in the region. King George I sought its destruction via two means: a pardon for all who turned themselves in, and a relentless counterattack towards all who would not. Upon hearing this, roughly half of the pirates surrendered, including Hornigold – who immediately was placed in charge of hunting his former proteges.
The shattering of the Republic led to the “Golden Age” of piracy in the Caribbean, as the now-decentralized pirates dispersed to make their fortune in every corner of the sea.

Havana was one of the most significant settlements in the colonial Caribbean, and one of the hearts of Spanish power in the region. An excellent harbor just at the beginning point of the Gulf Stream – that warm current of water that served as a highway leading back to Europe (not to mention the reason for Europe’s warm climate relative to other places at its latitude), the harbor at Havana was geographically situated to extend power across the major and minor islands of the region, and beyond.

As such, it was the place where treasure fleets would assemble before making the dangerous trip back to Spain. The Crown thought that a fortified fleet would prove better protected from the pirates that even by the 16th century had begun to plague the area. This calculation proved true… but also made the fleet a tempting prize for any who might take it.

Fortifications began in the harbor in 1553, and were expanded as the English, French and Dutch presence in the region grew. The fortress fell to an English siege in 1762, but remained formidable throughout the age of sail, and beyond.
Havana became the capital of an independent Cuba in 1902, though the utility of sea fortresses has waned in an era of cruise missiles and stealth bombers.

A naval arsenal is a structure for the repair and construction of naval vessels, and is a major outpost of naval power for seafaring nations. But the Republic of Pirates was no such nation. Historically, the Republic was a short-lived takeover of a minor colonial outpost. Its navy – if such a term can come to be used for such an unorganized mass of independent actors – was made up of stolen ships crewed by people of dozens of nations. As such, it did not command a naval arsenal – ship construction (rather than theft) was not a feature of New Providence, and repairs were done in shallow water in the harbor. But were the Republic to grow and expand, it might have made its own arsenal, raising a vital challenge against the powers of the seafaring nations.

If the arsenal is the building for ships’ construction, the station (or, simply, naval base) is a building for ships’ restock and resupply. These could be major installations or smaller outposts to assist a ship on its voyage. Even with a perfectly sound ship, even with powder kept secure and dry, crews needed their own maintenance – seawater cannot be drunk, and rations needed to be stocked. Further, before 1747, the scourge of scurvy seemed to visit all who stayed on the sea for too long and failed to come into port from time to time (the solution to scurvy, of course, was a lack of vitamin C – a shipboard diet of cured meat and bread contained no fresh fruit or vegetables), thus making well-stocked naval stations vital for the maintenance of naval power.

The governors of colonial cities faced challenges. They were reliant upon protection from powers based an ocean away, often in the middle of territory partially controlled by rival nations and the indigenous inhabitants who resented their presence – all the while sitting upon vast potential wealth. Is it any wonder that many struck deals with pirates for protection, for supplies, or just for wealth?

In the Caribbean, Tortuga, New Providence, and Port Royal were famous havens. In Africa, St. Mary’s Island supplied pirates working the Indian Ocean trade, and in Indonesia, Sulawesi and the Sulu islands were likewise pirate havens.

“To go on account” meant, in the pirate lingo of the early 18th century, to sign up to be a pirate. And what one signed would be the Articles of Agreement. Also often called a “pirate code,” this was a list of rules that bound crew and captain in a sort of limited autocracy while the ship was at sea, a bubble of alternate governance unbound to nation or land. Signing the Articles also marked one as being a pirate in the eyes of the imperial powers of the time.

These varied often from ship to ship, but often contained a certain amount of rights. Pirates who signed the Articles could vote for important decisions and be assured of a share of plunder, but were also bound by rules while on board: no uncovered pipes below-decks, no music on Sundays, no women on board, no quarrels. At times, the democratic provisions in the Articles were far freer than that of imperial navies at the time, and this idea of independence and guaranteed rights were a draw for many who had faced abuse at the hands of a British or French naval captain.

The sea can be a hostile place. Ships damaged by battle or storms or running low on supplies needed places where they could securely rest, restock and repair. For pirates, the risks were increased, as such a place needed to be hidden from naval patrols and distant from the bureaucratic reach of imperial powers.

But such places existed. Pirate waters lay especially where geography became difficult – around warrens of narrow channels and treacherous islands, near major shipping lanes. The Sulu Archipleagio, for instance, in present-day Indonesia; Madagascar, near where ships would round the Cape of Good Hope and head north towards Asia; and, of course, the Caribbean. In some places, such as Port Royal or New Providence, pirates could pay colonial authorities to turn a blind eye to their activities; in others, local powers resistant to major European trade networks might encourage pirate activity. Each would provide a valuable port of call for raiders seeking rest and resupply.

Colonialism needed sea lanes. The wealth mined, grown, or plundered in colonies was concentrated, loaded onto ships and sent across thousands of miles of trackless sea towards the mother country (or, in the case of the Manila trade, sent to trade with China). Unlike rival powers, who might seek to dominate the colonial system, and unlike independence movements that sought to build systems of their own, piracy attacked its very existence. Thus, pirates have since ancient times been categorized by states as, in Latin, “hostis humani generis,” enemies of all, opening pirates up to attack and retribution by any power. Pirates, of course, saw themselves differently – occasionally as lovers of freedom, or occasionally (as Henry Avery put it) as men “of fortune, (who) must seek their fortune.”

A buccaneer is a general term for a pirate, but the word itself has an etymology that extends beyond. In the 17th century, as livestock from colonial settlements escaped and grew feral, Hispaniola gained a population of wild pigs – and some settlers, too, escaped and grew feral. These outlaws were named “buccaneers,” after the Arawak word (buccan) for a meat-grilling stand. By the time that more Europeans had arrived in the area, the word had come to mean anyone living off of brigandry and piracy – especially as colonial authorities tried to eradicate these lawless individuals and their feral prey and many sought employment and gain by plunder.

On the horizon, a sloop is almost immediately recognizable – a triangular mass of sails almost obscuring the thin, knifelike hull beneath. Defined mostly by its rigging – a single mast with a mainsail, and a sail or sails mounted in the fore, a sloop is built for speed. Its shallow draft meant that it could sail across treacherous waters where more heavily-built ships might founder, and the extensive sails meant that it was extremely fast. It may have lacked the heavy cargo holds or firepower of a larger ship, but the sloop was perfect for quick raids – and quick escapes.

Republic of Pirates Unique Production Building. +5[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production. +1[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production Adjacency for Military Buildings, Gold Buildings, and Wonders. Ageless. Must be placed on Coast. Has no [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold maintenance.
Must be placed on Coast.[n]Republic of Pirates Unique Building.
Republic of Pirates Unique Gold Building. +4[icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold. +1[icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold Adjacency for Resources and Wonders. Ageless. Must be placed on Coast.
Must be placed on Coast.[n]Republic of Pirates Unique Building.

Republic of Pirates Unique Quarter. Created by constructing the Naval Station and Naval Arsenal in the same District. +1 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold for every [icon:TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Resource in your Pool. Friendly Naval Units receive +50 [icon:Action_Heal] Healing in this tile.
+1 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold for every [icon:TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Resource in your Pool. Friendly Naval Units receive +50 [icon:Action_Heal] Healing in this tile.

+3 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold. This Settlement generates [icon:UNIT_TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Convoys worth 3 Treasure Fleet points in the Exploration Age. +1 [icon:ATTRIBUTE_ECONOMIC] Economic Attribute Point. Ageless. Must be built in Distant Lands Coast adjacent to Land that is not a Lake.

This Settlement generates [icon:UNIT_TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Convoys worth 3 Treasure Fleet points in the Exploration Age. +1 [icon:ATTRIBUTE_ECONOMIC] Economic Attribute Point.[N]Must be built in Distant Lands Coast adjacent to Land that is not a Lake.
In the immediate nearness of the gold, all else had been forgotten.
"Yes, I do heartily repent. I repent I had not done more mischief."
"Heaven, you fool? Did you ever hear of any pirate going thither? Give me hell, it's a merrier place."
"I am a man of fortune, and must seek my fortune."
[icon:UNIT_BUCCANEER] Buccaneers gain the [icon:NAR_REW_PROMOTION] Looting Promotion for free.
[icon:UNIT_BUCCANEER] Buccaneers gain 1 charge to create a new [icon:YIELD_TOWNS] Town.
+15 [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength for all Military Units against [icon:UNIT_TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Convoys.
When you capture a [icon:UNIT_TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Convoy Unit, it is worth an additional Treasure Fleet Point.
+50%[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production towards Naval Units for every [icon:UNIT_FLEET_COMMANDER] Fleet Commander you have.
Merry Life and a Short One

When you defeat a Support Unit, gain [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold equal to the Unit’s [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production cost. When you defeat a Naval Unit, gain [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold equal to 25% of the Unit’s [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production cost.

Ahoy, bucko! Ye’ve gone on account with those who ken no lord but the sea and the salt. Weigh anchor, then, an see if it be gold or Jack Ketch at the end of yer gangway. The writ’s been signed, an the devil’s afoot.
Since the Republic of Pirates are unable to train Settlers, unlock the Ports of Call Civic to give the Buccaneer Unique Commander a charge to create a new Town.
Contains a new Exploration Age Civilization, Republic of Pirates.

Activate on an unoccupied tile adjacent to a Treasure Resource owned by a different Civilization in Distant Lands. This Settlement instantly spawns a Treasure Convoy under your Control, this does not reset the turns until another Treasure Convoy spawns.
Requires an adjacent and unoccupied Treasure Resource tile owned by a different Civilization in Distant Lands.

A pirate code of conduct seems a contradiction, but here it stands, drafted, ready for ratification by a council of pirates. “Bit thin,” remarks a haggard old seafarer. “Could use some more notes,” says another.
Scribes have worked for years to refine the Code. It stands now on wrinkled vellum – a monument to pirate solidarity. “Bit thick,” remarks the old sailor. “Too long to read,” says another.
The Norman sailors fancy themselves sea dogs, scourges of the waters. The pirates cannot abide another laying claim to their domain.
Ensure that the seas remain under the black flag.
Sea dogs can bark all they want, but they remain on land.
The Five Hundred Lords of the Chola Empire are merchant kings, draped in gold and jewels, their names synonymous with wealth and luxury. Today, one has walked the plank. How many Lords are left?
Four Hundred and Ninety-Nine Lords meet Four Hundred and Ninety-Nine Swords.
Use a Buccaneer's "Raiding Party" action against the Chola.
The Lost Treasure of the Ming
The purser paces the length of the captured Ming vessel. After going over the numbers again and again, she reaches a conclusion: a sizeable part of the treasure has gone missing.
It comes out of the captain’s share.

The initial reports come in: a ship, laden with wealth, en route to pirate harbors. But as the weeks turn to months with no ship, the plans for spending this wealth turn to grumbles. Eventually, a captain returns – the ship, he claims, is in another’s hands.
The bosun of the treasure fleet surrenders along with the rest of the crew. With a sigh of exasperation, he signals that the pirate flag be flown from the mast. Again.
A good lashing will ensure this does not happen again.
Another treasure fleet has gone missing, another sack of excuses given at admiralty headquarters. The admiral looks at the captain suspiciously. “Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice…”
“Shame on me.” Seize the captain’s assets.
Black Sails on the High Seas
Over the seas, the pirates reign. They come from all nations of the world, speaking every tongue known to humanity, all with one overriding goal:

The workers on distant sites toil tirelessly in the sun, gleaning treasures from the land, treasures snatched, taken up, and loaded on ships bound for the motherland. In turn, these treasure ships are halted, boarded, and their goods taken up and bound for the Republic of Pirates.
The profits shall inspire new crews.
Workers, like sailors, deserve a share.

Those pirates who remember the Republic of antiquity have formed a new center of power in the new, distant settlement. They declare that it will be a city different from all others – a place entirely free of chains and shackles – of both mind and body.
Declare it the island of the free!

The Orang Laut – a group once within the Majapahit Empire, and now in the Republic of Pirates – spend their entire lives on the sea. Homes rock with the waves, residents fish from their docks, and children seem just as at ease in the sea as on the land.
They shall pilot the fishing fleet.
Dr. Rizal on the Open Sea

Though no stranger to ships, Dr. Rizal feels uneasy on the deck of the pirate sloop. Violence seems to simmer under the surface, and each of these sailors has a gallows waiting for them in some foreign port.
Befriend one. They might cut the doctor in on some loot.
A rare chance to see them in action!
The Found Treasure of the Ming
As workmen tear up the remnants of an old pirate inn, under the flooboards they discover a trove of plundered Ming valuables.
The treasures shall grace a museum of the pirate age.

Underneath an old wharf, construction workers find an enormous stash of gold – treasure pilfered from the old Republic of Pirates. The loot is of historical importance, but also is raw bullion that could feed {1_Civilization_Adj} coffers.
Sell it and feed the income to the treasury.
It is a window into the golden era of pirates!

Republic of Pirates Unique Light Naval Unit. Can cross borders of other Civilizations, [icon:Action_Pillage] Plunder Trade Routes between non-Allied Civilizations, and attack Units of non-Allied Civilizations without going to [icon:WAR] War. Defeating a unit with the Sloop provides [icon:YIELD_GOLD]Gold equal to 100% of that unit's [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength. Can move after attacking and has 5 [icon:Action_Move] Movement.

Republic of Pirates Tier 1 Light Naval Unit. Can cross borders of other Civilizations, [icon:Action_Pillage] Plunder Trade Routes between non-Allied Civilizations, and attack Units of non-Allied Civilizations without going to [icon:WAR] War. Defeating a unit with the Sloop provides [icon:YIELD_GOLD]Gold equal to 100% of that unit's [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength. Can move after attacking and has 5 [icon:Action_Move] Movement.

Republic of Pirates Tier 2 Light Naval Unit. Can cross borders of other Civilizations, [icon:Action_Pillage] Plunder Trade Routes between non-Allied Civilizations, and attack Units of non-Allied Civilizations without going to [icon:WAR] War. Defeating a unit with the Sloop provides [icon:YIELD_GOLD]Gold equal to 100% of that unit's [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength. Can move after attacking and has 5 [icon:Action_Move] Movement.

Republic of Pirates Tier 3 Light Naval Unit. Can cross borders of other Civilizations, [icon:Action_Pillage] pillage trade routes between non-Allied Civilizations, and attack units of non-Allied Civilizations without going to [icon:WAR] War. Defeating a unit with the Sloop provides [icon:YIELD_GOLD]Gold equal to 100% of that unit's [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength. Can move after attacking and has 5 [icon:Action_Move] Movement.

Republic of Pirates Unique Naval Commander. Gains 1 charge to use the Raiding Party Action for every 2 [icon:NAR_REW_PROMOTION] Levels it has. Raiding Party: Targets an adjacent [icon:TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Resource owned by a different Civilization in Distant Lands. This Settlement instantly spawns a [icon:UNIT_TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Convoy under your control. This does not reset the turns until another [icon:UNIT_TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Convoy spawns.
[B]Plundering[/B] was an important part of [B]Republic of Pirates's[/B] identity.

No one can watch the whole sea. As trade grows, so do the chances for plunder. Pirates grow increasingly organized and increasingly bold. It is only a matter of time before they make a bid for something greater.
[B]Edward Teach[/B] was the most feared pirate of the [B]Republic of Pirates[/B].
[B]Amina[/B] and the [B]Republic of Pirates[/B] both like Gold and Resources.
As the Republic of Pirates, complete an Economic Legacy Path.
As the Republic of Pirates, complete the Havana Harbor.
